Hi! I'm hoping someone can help me with this. I know it's a common problem but all the fixes I read about online involve using "bootcfg.exe" and I have the HOME edition of XP - meaning I don't have access to it because bootcfg is available in the XP PRO version ONLY. So your help is greatly appreciated! Thanks in advance!!
1. I did a full backup (image) of my C: drive which contains the XP OS and all my files (I used ShadowProtect Desktop v. 3.2 if that's any help) and saved the image to an external USB hard drive. 2. I restored the image to my F: Drive. This is my 2nd Hard Drive. It was copied to a primary partition on the F: Drive which was newly formatted. 3. I edited the boot.ini file to now include the F: drive as an option to boot from but when I tried to boot from it, I got an error message that said "Windows could not start because of a computer disk hardware configuration problem" I should mention that when I did the restore, I did NOT check off any of the options "Set Partition Active", "Restore MBR" or "Restore Disk Hidden Track". I don't want to make the F: drive the active partition and I was afraid to check "Restore MBR" out of fear that it might overwrite the one on the C: drive or mess it up somehow at which point I would have NO clue how to restore it to its original state. The thought of not being able to boot to either and having to re-install XP on my C: drive and wipe it out is a bit too scary right now. Here is my new boot.ini file (in which I added the "XP Test" or F: Drive) It currently defaults to the C: Drive \[boot loader\] timeout=30 default=multi(0)disk(0)rdisk(0)partition(2)\\WINDOWS \[operating systems\] multi(0)disk(0)rdisk(0)partition(2)\\WINDOWS="Microsoft Windows XP Home Edition" /fastdetect multi(0)disk(1)rdisk(0)partition(1)\\WINDOWS="XP Test" /fastdetect /NoExecute=OptIn partition(2) IS CORRECT by the way and disk(0) refers to my C: drive. Hope this is enough info for you to go on :-) Can you please tell me what's happening, why, and how I can fix it so that I can boot from either hard drive successfully? Thanks so much!!!!

Hmmm, ![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif), some good news and some bad news.  

The good news ![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif) are that you do not need bootcfg.exe, as it would not be of any use.  

The bad news ![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif) are that what you are trying to do is actually one of the MOST DIFFICULT things to do with a XP install.  

According to the good MS guys it's impossible, and actually, though possible, is VERY, VERY tricky.  

It resolves to BOTH (and at the same time):  
1) migrating a XP install to another drive  
2) changing the XP System drive letter  

Read this:  
[http://www.msfn.org/...art-t90495.html](http://www.msfn.org/board/Change-Boot-Drive-Letter-for-System-Part-t90495.html "External link")  

and these:  
[http://www.michaelst.../moving_xp.html](http://www.michaelstevenstech.com/moving_xp.html "External link")  
[http://www.michaelst...pairinstall.htm](http://www.michaelstevenstech.com/XPrepairinstall.htm "External link")  
[http://www.goodells....ot/partsigs.htm](http://www.goodells.net/multiboot/partsigs.htm "External link")  

(and links therein)  

I do not want to put you down, mind you ![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif), but you must be prepared to spend quite a bit of time on attempting to do the above and WITHOUT ANY guarantee that you will be able to have it working at all.  

Can you explain the reasons why you are trying to do what you described? ![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif)  

jaclaz

forumNotes.author: ilko
forumNotes.content:
> ...Here is my new boot.ini file (in which I added the "XP Test" or F: Drive) It currently defaults to the C: Drive  
>
> \[boot loader\]  
> timeout=30  
> default=multi(0)disk(0)rdisk(0)partition(2)\\WINDOWS  
> \[operating systems\]  
> multi(0)disk(0)rdisk(0)partition(2)\\WINDOWS="Microsoft Windows XP Home Edition" /fastdetect  
> multi(0)disk(1)rdisk(0)partition(1)\\WINDOWS="XP Test" /fastdetect  
> /NoExecute=OptIn  
>
> partition(2) IS CORRECT by the way and disk(0) refers to my C: drive.  
> ...
Don't touch disk, change rdisk(X).  
[http://support.microsoft.com/kb/102873](http://support.microsoft.com/kb/102873 "External link")  

If Windows was cloned on the second disk, first partition, then the line for it in BOOT.INI is:  

```
multi(0)disk(0)rdisk(1)partition(1)\WINDOWS="XP Test" /fastdetect
```

The other steps are in the links Jaclaz gave you.  

Basically you have 2 options-   
1) make the second drive (F) to appear as drive C, and the original C as something else  
2) change all references in registry from C: to F:  

As said results are not guaranteed.

forumNotes.author: ilko
forumNotes.content:
Ohh, sorry, we have posted at the same time.  

XP Setup does not need boot.ini (apart from detecting previous Windows-es), hence your problem will not be resolved by bootcfg.exe.  

Is this the exact message you are getting when booting from the CD? I believe this comes from NTLDR(wrong boot.ini path), and you booted from a hard disk. Double check boot order please.  

A few options to try:  
Disconnect the Vista disk and connect ONLY your new disk. Does Setup still hang?  
If no- is using BIOS to choose hard disk boot order convenient for you? This way you can boot into Vista or XP. If no- we can use grub4dos to do the boot part.  
Would the installed XP hang if Vista disk is connected?  
What's the hardware on that machine?

forumNotes.author: ilko
forumNotes.content:
> My only concern with disconnecting the HD that Vista is on and connecting the 2nd IDE HD and trying to install XP on that (assuming I can get past that blue screen) is that XP will then install itself on the Hard Drive thinking it's the C: drive and assign that path to all registry entries... so that when I re-connect the HD Vista is on, XP won't be able to boot properly because C: will now point to Vista not XP (which will be F: )
"C" gets the first disk/first primary partition according to BIOS boot settings. At boot time drive letter doesn't play role, it comes into effect much later.  
So you should be safe to install XP while the SATA disk is disconnected and boot it later on by changing BIOS order.  
When you boot VISTA- SATA disk/PART1 will be C.  
When you boot XP- IDE disk/PART1 will be C.  
Good enough?  

Lack of free primary partitions should not cause error messages- one may want to (delete one of them and) install there.  

The error message you were referring does not exist in SETUPLDR.BIN, so I assume XP setup was not started at all.  

The request to install XP on the new PC, with only IDE disk connected is also for troubleshooting.  

On second read- my **guess** what happened is that when you added the IDE disk, with wrong boot.ini on it, it became FIRST boot device, rather than your CD with XP in it. Hence the error message you got, it didn't come from the XP Setup.  
Double check boot order in BIOS while both disks are attached and make it boot your XP CD. Leave the other steps for later if this doesn't work.
